newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian share trading improves as traders return.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian share trading improves as traders return.

text.p: Trading rose on the Nigerian bourse on Tuesday as more brokers shook off their unease with a newly-installed computerised clearing system, dealers said.
The all-share index, however, fell a touch to 8778.39 from 8778.40 on Monday, the first day of operating the new system.
Dealers said more houses participated in trading compared with the only three that were able to conduct business the day before.
"More dealers lodged their share certificates yesterday and so were able to trade today," one said, adding "Many people are still trying to see how the system works before resuming business fully."
Prices rose in general although movement was mainly restricted to blue chip stocks, traders said.
Food/beverages companies dominated the trend, led by Coco-Cola bottler Nigerian Bottling Company which gained one naira to 56.00 naira.
Nestle remained the sector's dearest stock, advancing 10 kobo to 70.15 naira. Cadbury also rose 20 kobo to 40.00 naira, all on increased demand.
Leading conglomerates also finished firmer. Lever Brothers and PZ Industries each gained 50 kobo to 29.10 naira and 29.50 naira, respectively.
UAC continued to be investors' favourite, closing 30 kobo higher at 19.80 naira.
Not much action was recorded in the banks although UBA garnered 20 kobo to end at 15.30 naira.
Troubled Berger Paints recovered on Tuesday, advancing 15 kobo to 3.90 naira.
Agricultural company Ellah Lakes which returned to profit saw its price adjusted to its quotation price of 50 kobo from 10 kobo.
